Jul 26, 2018( Gotham Gazette: http://www.gothamgazette.com Delivered by Newstex) Zephyr Teachout (photo: Gotham Gazette) Democratic Attorney General hopeful Zephyr Teachout is placing the blame for mass layoffs at the New York Daily News on tech giants Google and Facebook, and plans, if elected, to enforce antitrust laws to battle what she calls a 'duopoly' of ad revenue that is crushing local news. Referring to big tech as a 'parasite on journalism,' Teachout unveiled on Wednesday a broad, though somewhat vague, plan to use the antitrust laws available to state and federal prosecutors to break up Google and Facebook's stranglehold on the news business. In the wake of tronc, the Daily News' parent company, laying off half the publication's staff on Monday, much of the blame has been pinned on the corporation and its executives. According to the Daily Beast, tronc executives told remaining Daily News staff that they had no strategy behind the mass layoffs.

Meanwhile, former tronc board chair Michael Ferro, who left the company in March amid a sexual harassment scandal, received a $15 million severance package from the company, drawing criticism. Teachout, however, says that targeting tronc, while necessary, is piecemeal and would do nothing to save local news. 'I'll look into illegality wherever it is, or any issues that fall within the jurisdiction of the AG's office,' Teachout said at a Wednesday press conference outside the Daily News headquarters in lower Manhattan. 'But I can't repeat this enough. If we don't actually deal with the systemic, structural issues that are squeezing out and starving local journalism, if we keep treating these as one-offs, we're gonna keep losing local news.' The larger issues Teachout was referring to were the heavy concentration of digital ad revenue with Google and Facebook, which she said transferred revenue from journalists and publications into the hands of tech giants. She cited a December report[1] from research firm eMarketer estimating that 63 percent of all digital ad revenue in 2017 belonged to the two companies. Microsoft and Oath each accounted for 11.8 percent of revenue, while Amazon took 5.4 percent. Other reports, such as one from software firm Pivotal[2], estimated Google and Facebook's duopoly at 73 percent of digital ad revenue in 2017. Though Facebook and Google still are clearly the dominant forces in online advertising, their share of the market appears to be slipping somewhat, according to the same firm cited by Teachout. A post[3] from March suggests that Google and Facebook will see their share of digital ad revenue decline to 56.8 percent this year, and continue slipping in 2019 and 2020 as companies like Amazon and Snapchat grow their ad businesses faster than the two current juggernauts. None of it points toward ad revenue returning toward news publications themselves. Meanwhile, Facebook's profit margins are, according to Teachout, over 40 percent. 'Local newspapers around the country are getting decimated as the digital ad revenue is dropping and being shifted from the newspapers themselves, the journalists themselves, to Google and Facebook,' Teachout said, referring to this as the 'ad tech tax.' Teachout said that lax antitrust enforcement had allowed Google and Facebook to acquire companies and become massive juggernauts in the advertising industry. She said that she would work with other state attorneys general to bring a 'major antitrust investigation to look into the ways in which Facebook and Google are wielding and maybe abusing their duopoly powers.' She also proposed 'rigorous enforcement' of state and federal antitrust statutes, like the state's Donnelly Act, preventing anticompetitive business practices, and the federal Clayton Act, to prevent the proliferation of monopolistic mergers, to bust the duopoly. As such, she wants to break up Google and Facebook in such a way that creates 'healthy ad markets' with hundreds of firms making lower profit margins, and more revenue going to publications and journalists. In that vein, she hopes to block large mergers and acquisitions by companies like Facebook, citing its acquisition of Instagram as an antitrust violation -- both had been competing in the market for user-created photo content. 'We should explore breaking up these companies to allow for healthy ad markets which are necessary to support affordable access to news,' Teachout said. 'So instead of newspapers begging for access to readers through Facebook and Google, what we should have instead is a healthy, vibrant, competitive ad market with hundreds of digital ad brokers competing -- with a profit margin, but not 40 percent profit margin -- competing for the attention of those news organizations.' Responding to a question from Gotham Gazette, Teachout said that Google and Facebook were able to achieve such dominance in the online ad market because their mergers and acquisitions had been allowed to proceed at a hectic pace with little regulatory scrutiny. As such, if the companies were to be broken up into hundreds of smaller ad companies, and enforcement and legislative statutes prevented new mergers from taking place, then a newly competitive market would be sustained by government intervention and the share of revenue demanded by the firms would decrease. 'There isn't actually a competitive market for different ways to reach readers,' Teachout said. The Fordham Law professor and constitutional scholar discussed her antitrust plans on the same day she received good news about a lawsuit she helped craft against President Donald Trump, for his alleged violation of the emoluments clause of the U.S. Constitution, which is said to prohibit payments from foreign governments to the president of the United States. A judge, citing Teachout's work, ruled that a case brought by the attorneys general of Maryland and Washington, D.C. could proceed. Teachout is facing New York City Public Advocate Letitia James, U.S. Representative Sean Patrick Maloney, and Leecia Eve, a former aide to Governor Andrew Cuomo, in the Democratic primary for Attorney General. The vote is September 13. One area of antitrust action Teachout said she would pursue would be to prevent Facebook from using its platform to host both news from outside sources, like the Daily News or Gotham Gazette, and its own news content, such as the presentation of trending topics alongside posts from news services. Teachout referred to this as a 'clear' violation of antitrust laws. She also said she would support state legislation to prevent content discrimination on social media platforms, saying that large media organizations like the New York Times could afford to cut deals to better promote their content in a way that a smaller outlet -- she cited the Poughkeepsie Journal -- could not. 'I do see it as a combination of legislation and enforcement, but we gotta start with enforcement. We're just not even enforcing existing laws.' JOHN MCADAM, PRESIDENT, CEO & DIRECTOR, F5 NETWORKS, INC.: All right, I am just going to start. So if you are outside the room right now, I'm just starting the conference. So good morning, everybody. My name is John McAdam. If you don't know me, I'm President and CEO of F5. Welcome to our annual Analyst and Investor Day.

The agenda here is pretty straightforward. I think you're going to find it pretty useful this morning. As usual, I just do the introduction. I'll be involved very much in the Q&A, and then our team mobile will do the presentations.

There is a lot going on with us right now. I feel really, really good about where we sit in the industry and our position and our strategic position specifically. If you look at this year that is coming up -- actually, let's look at last year just for a second. Last year, I said on the call it was really a game of two halves. Q1 and Q2 was pretty tough; obviously Q2, the March quarter, was a tough one. [Turndown] was pretty tough for the whole industry. But I felt really good about Q3, Q4 and our momentum moving into fiscal 2014.

I think the big mistake we made last year -- just talking about mistakes -- I know companies don't often do that -- our product refresh took too long. It was too elongated and it lasted almost a year. The good news is as we move into this fiscal year, it's all done. It's a done deal. We are coming in with a whole range of new products.

We had our sales conference just recently and the mood was really upbeat. I think we have got some absolutely clear, tangible drivers to grow our product revenue, which, as you all know, is our main focus, as the ACE replacement has been -- the momentum there is excellent. We have done over 900 replacements there since we started. We think we have got really good opportunity.

You may have noticed that we actually are now a partner of Cisco, a pretty significant partner, I think, as we move forward, as we are with companies like VMware. But I think that is going to help as well in that specific scenario.

Service provider has been lumpy, clearly. But again, we have got a bunch of business drivers in that space. The LTE rollout with Traffix, we feel really good about that. Our win rate is increasing. Dave Feringa will talk about some of the wins that we have done there. But we really do believe that that Diameter solution we have is the best out there in the market. We have introduced new functionality, like the policy enforcement manager and products like that.

Probably in service provider the biggest opportunity is security and security with our access products, security with our application firewall. But more importantly, with our advanced firewall manager, which is the traditional firewall product that is ideal for saving money, but also protecting against DDoS attacks and areas like that because of its performance. So we feel really, really good about that as well.

So a whole bunch of drivers I think are going to accelerate our product revenue growth this year as we move forward.

The big thing I really feel good about is our strategic position. I know there has been a lot of concern and discussion and all that stuff about software-defined networking. I really -- I compare it a little bit to what happened in virtualization, when VMware started coming up with their virtualization products. Everybody -- oh my God, F5's value-add is going to diminish. It was the opposite. I think exactly the same thing is going to happen with our strategic position with SDN.

We announced our Synthesis architecture you are going to hear about in great detail today as well, and it really puts us in a really, really strong position. After -- we announced our Synthesis architecture on Tuesday of last week, and after that on Thursday, we announced the ecosystem. And you should take a look at that press release, the companies that are involved in talking and working with us. All the SDN players are deeply working with us, and not just at the marketing level of press announcements, but actually technology relationships, and we will talk about that as well. VMware, Cisco, obviously OpenStack is a standard. HP, Dell, companies like that. So we are in a really strong position here, because we have this value-add of understanding what is happening at the application level, and you are going to hear a lot about that today.

So that is all I have got to say. I will obviously be back at the Q&A, and I hope it is an interesting morning. In terms of the presentations, if you could keep questions to a minimum of maybe even zero -- if that's possible -- and then we will have quite a long time for Q&A later today. So okay. So Manny, yes.

MANNY RIVELO, EVP OF STRATEGIC SOLUTIONS, F5 NETWORKS, INC.: Good morning, everybody. So let me back up, please. So Manny Rivelo, EVP of Strategic Solutions for F5. I have been with F5 for two years, and prior to that, I was with Cisco for almost 20 years, a month shy of 20 years.

My goal today is simply to explain to you our strategy and our vision of the Company and to give you an indication of what we rolled out to the industry last week. Then I am going to turn it over to Karl, and Karl will go through the products that actually bring this vision to reality.

I talk a little about the time is right for this vision, and the reality of it is, it couldn't be any better with all the changes that are going on in the market segment. And there has been a big gap, and I will talk a little bit about that gap that's been left in the industry, which is really about layer 4 through 7. There has been a lot of conversation -- John talked about that conversation that is happening around SDN. But the reality is layer 4 through 7 services have not been dealt with in an ideal way in the industry.

And what we are doing is we are inserting into that gap in the industry and ensuring that the whole stack, if you will, the whole OSI stack is fully integrated in a dynamic fashion to bring that to market.

Now, last week was a big coming out for this architecture and it was a big coming out for the Company as a whole, because if you look at the events that happened last week, on Monday, we were part of the Arista announcement around their spline architecture. They launched it here in New York. On Tuesday, we launched our Synthesis architecture. On Wednesday, we were part of Cisco's application-centric infrastructure architecture. Thursday, we announced our ecosystem. Just yesterday, we announced strategic partnerships with Amazon around utility-base pricing for cloud-based services. And today, we had a big announcement at the LTE Summit around our Diameter stack and our solutions and awards that we are winning there. So a lot of activity is going on around F5 and we expect a lot more. And this architecture is really targeted at capturing that.

Where we focus is predominantly on three markets, and I will talk a lot more about that, and that is security, cloud and mobility. And when I talk about mobility, I am talking about it both from an enterprise perspective, mobile devices, but also from a carrier perspective in the mobile operators.

Our target, our sales addressable market that we go after -- and this is fully -- that we could cover every one of these dollars with our solutions. We did a lot of work around this. It is a little bit over $6 billion market; it is actually $6.4 billion market. So what we are launching is an architecture to go after $6.4 billion in 2014.

This market will extend itself, based on our roadmap, to about $18 billion by 2017. And that is what we are targeting. Now this is about four times the traditional ADC market. Towards the tail end of my presentation, I will go through it, and I will show you how it is composed and what are the submarkets and how we get to that $6.4 billion opportunity. So a significant opportunity, and we want to go capture that from an architecture point of view.

The reality of it is that the market is going through a lot of shifts and a lot of technology shifts that are being created out there. You are familiar with these, so I am not going to go through them in a lot of detail; I'll just touch on them. But obviously, mobility, we all know. Mobile devices are exploding. There is more smart phones than there are PCs. That threshold was crossed a couple of years ago. By 2015, there is going to be more tablets than there are PCs out there. The workforce is mobile, the workforce is always on. That creates a whole new set of opportunities in the market segment that need to be addressed, because customers want similar experiences in the mobile world as they have in the traditional world.

Cloud applications are on the move. You are seeing a lot of comments around bring your own app, BYOA, now, right? Where your app is actually moving, it is living in the cloud. As a matter of fact, cloud companies are growing at an immense rate. And if you talk to most enterprises, over 70% of enterprises out there have a cloud strategy. And that means moving workloads to the cloud. Some of those have started in dev and test environments, but the reality is they have a significant cloud strategy.

The threats. With all this movement, the boundaries have disappeared. There is a new set of threats. We read a lot about malware, we read about application attacks, we read a lot about losing PII information in the industry. So software-defined, there is this concept that software-defined networking was going to just change everything, the whole landscape is going to change. Really, software-defined networking -- or software-defined everything is about automation and orchestration, and separation of the data plane from the control plane and being able to deliver services much more dynamically in an environment. So it's actually a very good opportunity for us to participate in.

The Internet of Things, there is a lot of talk about the Internet of Things. All that means is there is going to be more signaling. There is a signaling tsunami coming. We all read about that. Everything needs to communicate over a 4G network, and as a result of that, need to address those problems in the industry.

And then of course there is something that very few companies talk about -- we end up talking a lot about it -- which is the workloads, the traffic. The protocol of the Internet has become http. And when you are dealing with http, you are not dealing with packets anymore; what you have to deal with is the flow. It's a different way of architecting your network. So as a result of that, all of these opportunities are significant and they all have massive implications on applications.

Now, the reality is we have been positioning the Company around this vision, which is really about the delivery of applications reliably secure and accelerated, anywhere, anyplace, anytime. And that has been what we have been building to, which has positioned us really well to capture on these changes that are happening in the industry.

The evolution of the Company, which I would say we are in the fourth phase of our evolution -- you could actually argue there is a phase zero, and you could say phase zero was the founding of the Company around load balancing. But back in about 2003, 2004, the Company moved from being a traditional load balancer and build a platform, the TMOS platform -- Karl will talk a lot about that today -- which was a full proxy architecture. By bringing that platform to market, it really opened up a lot of opportunity for us as a Company.

First of all it, allowed us to, yes, do traffic steering, traffic shaping. It allows us to offload services off of a server, accelerate connections, things of that nature. But it became the building block for what I would consider to be phase 2. And phase 2 is when we started to look at it and we said, there is other services that we could do inside that platform. We can begin to consolidate services in the industry. And these services traditionally have been point devices. So you could start consolidating security services -- for example, a firewall. So now you don't need a firewall sitting outside a load balancer. These services can be combined. And when you combine those services on one common platform, you could also chain those services dynamically based on flow.

So it gave us a platform to begin to consolidate services in the market segment. And I have listed some of the ones that are there. There is actually -- and I will talk a lot more about it -- there is a lot of services that we are consolidating.

The second point I will make on the slide is these layers continue. It is not as if we move to phase 2 and we are not innovating in phase 1. We are innovating a lot in phase 1. You will see a lot of conversation today about what we are doing around forward proxies. You will see innovation in layer 2 around secure Web Gateway things that we are launching to the market. So these layers will continue for time, forever, but obviously we are building on them.

The third, which is probably about two, maybe three years ago, was the whole cloud movement. And we realized we needed to make significant investments in cloud. And they came different ways. For one, it was all about ensuring that TMOS, our operating system, in all of the software modules can sit on any cloud, on every hypervisor in the industry that is a major hypervisor. So we support obviously VMware's ESXi, Microsoft's Hyper-V, Xen KVM. We even could put our workloads on AWS out there. We had a strategy to not only have all of our bits everywhere, but also continue to increase the performance of our virtual additions in the market.

We also believed that it was important to have the highest multi-tenancy in the industry. When you are dealing with cloud environments and you are selling to a cloud provider, they may want to buy a physical or a virtual piece of kit, but they might divide it and sell it to multiple customers. So a very, very strong push around the multi-tenancy characteristics.

Now, what has also been happening that we have been paying a lot of attention to is in the application environment. There has been a lot of changes in the application environment. About 5 to 7 years ago, you started to hear a lot about agile development. Now, the concept of agile development is really simple. All it means is you are listening to your customers, instead of going away for a year or two and writing an application, I am going to develop an application a lot quicker. I am going to do these sprints, usually about 8 weeks of work. I load the application out in the environment, people test it, I get feedback, I do more development. So agile has become a very popular software development tool specifically for cloud workloads in the environment.

And it was targeted at really delivering a lot of value. The problem with it is that agile by itself was a development methodology. It wasn't about deployment of the applications. There was this gap that has been left around how you deploy applications. And what we started to observe is that lots of corporations started to use the cloud. As I said, most organizations have cloud strategies. Most of them began to actually put some of their workloads or test their workloads on AWS or a Rackspace or Terremark or somebody else domestically, as well as internationally.

And so the cloud or DevOps became much more in vogue in the market segment. The problem with that is not all workloads can be in a public environment. Some of those workloads placed in a public environment have restrictions from an organization and/or don't have the right service levels that are out there, which sort of has given rise to this concept of SDN. SDN is the missing link. Because you could build an application fairly quickly through agile. You can deploy the application in your own private data center through a virtual instance, let's say, using VMware stack in a container. In the future, you will be able to also virtualize your storage and in the future you will be able to virtualize your network through SDN layers 2 and 3.

But there has been this void that has been left around 4 through 7 services. The reality is the applications also may need firewall services, load-balancing services, acceleration services, things of that nature. And that gap you are seeing is what we are filling in the market segment. We have intentionally pushed our strategy after that 4 through 7 gap as an organization, with a vision as a Company to deliver applications without constraint. That means your applications can roam, they can be placed anywhere, they should run where they run best. And then the services should follow that application.

So if the application needs security or acceleration, they will follow the applications in the environment, and that is what we are building as an overall organization, which has led to what we launched last week, which is this concept of Synthesis. And Synthesis is an architectural message really. It means that -- let me talk about it from this slide. What it basically means is that we are building our phase 4 of our architecture and it is around software-defined application services. It means defining those layer 4 through 7 services in software and be able to deliver those to the application much more dynamically.

Now, Synthesis itself has three major elements inside of it, and I am going to talk about each of those. It is really -- the first is the high-performance fabric, which is actually an elastic fabric. The second is the concept of automation orchestration, how you could deliver those services on any environment, because we basically sit on top of most environments that are out there. And the third is this concept of simplifying the business models. We heard from customers that they want options in how they procure our technology, not just perpetual licensing, but other options. So we have launched all three of those as part of the Synthesis architecture and we will continue to evolve on all three of those.

Just to talk about the first one a little bit, this high-performance fabric, the way to think about it is it sits on any network. If you can get a network to any of our devices, we can plug into that architecture and sit on top of that layer 2, if you will, layer 3 construct that is out there.

Now, what we do is we deliver a series of devices. These are the traditional devices that you see us talk a lot about. Virtual editions across all industry hypervisors, 1RU, 2RU appliances, fixed appliances that customers buy. And then these single-bladed chassis. And I use the word single-bladed because I think it is important. Our architecture has one line card, and you slap that line card. So we don't have a line card for a firewall and a line card for a load balancer and a line card for an acceleration device. That is all software. All our innovation is truly, truly software. The line cards are just boosting performance, and as you add line cards, the overall capability of the chassis just increases. These components that we built of these devices can be interconnected a whole bunch of different ways. And what we have been pushing a lot as part of our Phase 3 is this concept of scale-in. And scale-in is a technology architecture which allows you to either scale a device on-demand, meaning increase the performance through licensing, go from let's say a 5-gig to a 10-gig performance capability, so you could actually increase on demand. Or you could cluster devices together. And I will talk a little bit more about that, meaning you could take multiple devices and make them appear as one device, or you could take a device and partition that device or a cluster.

The partitioning is the multi-tenancy, and we do that in 2 ways. One way is we virtualize the actual partition all the way down to the operating system, which means I can have one device running three instances all the way down to the operating system. Or we could leave one operating system and do administrative partitions, where you basically partition the client, but it is still one version of VOS.

So scale-in allows you to leverage, if you will, these platforms, physical and virtual, and begin to configure them a whole bunch of different ways, giving you an elastic fabric in a multitenant fabric that is high, high performance.

Now, on the performance, here are some of the stats, just so you could see how incredible of a platform we could build. It is a 20-terabit throughput that we could build on that. We could cluster 32 devices. On any one device, we could have up to 80 partitions on that device. And then obviously, if you cluster devices together, the partitions go up.

Other stats that are pretty impressive is that 9.2 billion connections. We can provide on one cluster -- one multitenant cluster -- one connection for every user in the world -- more than one connection for every user in the world. So it is actually built for high, high performance, high scale. Obviously, you build that up as much as you want. And if you want one device, you want 32 devices, you can configure it that way. So that is a single cluster, very, very high performance.

All right. Software-defined networking. I had to put this in here, because it's just -- it has been such a misused term, I think, over the last three years, when it came out. And so again, when we talk about integrating with Cisco, we layer very nicely on top of their architecture. Now we also plug into things like SDN controllers. We also work with other -- like open source. So OpenStack has been -- we have been very involved with that. John, maybe you can walk us through how the deployments are taking place between virtual and [up line] based products and what the cost differential is. And then on the ACE opportunity you have talked about 900 customers so far, is there still significant growth in 2014 when you look at that opportunity? Thanks.

JOHN MCADAM: Yes, on the virtual side we have seen a variety of types of different types of sales. We have seen basically $1 million sales all software, we have seen -- and more than one of those. But they are still pretty rare when you are up to the high-end. Typically it is a hybrid sale that we have seen.

As we have increased our capability in BIG-IQ and ScaleN, which allows you to take a system and software and scale them together and manage them in one place. I think that will increase as well. So I think you're going to see more and more hybrid, but clearly if you have a horizontal scaling focus in your architecture as a customer cloud provider, you can see all software as well. So you are going to see the mix there.

In terms of the differential, it's not significant actually. If you look at the entry level 2000 and the price of the software version that's equivalent to that, it is about 80% roughly in that area.

SANJIV WADHWANI: (Inaudible - microphone inaccessible)?

JOHN MCADAM: I'm sorry? Oh, yes, absolutely. We think that is an opportunity that is going to be an opportunity over a number of years. We have done some more analysis. Manny, do you want to talk about that?

MANNY RIVELO: Yes. We did a top-down and bottoms-up analysis on the ACE opportunity. By looking at what Cisco has done over the last 10 years and then putting about a 50 -- discounting about 50% saying that has been replaced or not. And we are seeing an opportunity that is probably about $1 billion to $2 billion out there, still kits sitting out there.

Just like the question was asked, you have a lot of equipment out there that is five to seven years, there's a lot of ACE equipment. And in some of those accounts where we penetrated, some we discussed today in the use cases, we have only touched 20% of the installed base. So there is still repeat business.

So, John, dead on, it is a multi-year journey and they are going to pick -- move those components out over time. The interesting part is as they insert an ADC or let's say a BIG-IP into that equation is that quite often there is a secondary service that they enable. And that leads to the whole synthesis message and that is proving out very well as we replace ACE.

JOHN MCADAM: This is the final question and then we are done.

ROD HALL, ANALYST, JPMORGAN SECURITIES: Okay, I just have a question in 10 parts. No, I'm just kidding. It's Rod Hall with JPMorgan. Thanks for the questions. Two things I wanted to ask you about. One is on synergy, can you talk a little bit about the installed base and how much of it is synergy usable? And just kind of help us understand what sort of refresh might be necessary to implement synergy for customers that would be interested in it. That would be one thing.

And then at the other thing I wanted to ask you about is one of the things I have realized, maybe for obvious reasons, in the last several months is how some of these big customers -- the same problem -- you guys have this rich complex product and you have always struggled to get that message across to the financial community.

And I think I have just realized that is true for these big customers as well. They perceive you in a very vertical way. They look at particular applications and then once they get hold of the box, all of a sudden the realize, hey, this is thing is rich, there is all sorts of stuff we can do with it. How do you -- can you solve that problem and start to -- instead of starting so small start bigger with some of these big guys?

JOHN MCADAM: Right. Or better or best. By the way it is SYNTHESIS, Rod, SYNTHESIS the architecture, not synergy. But the whole SYNTHESIS is based on making that, if you like, complexity and it's not really complex, but that wealth of services more visible to the customer, more visible to our sales force. The packaging definitely in my opinion will help that quite tremendously because actually seeing we have this opportunity for you this one and this one, good, better, best. By definition you start a conversation about what you can do.

Because you are right, one of the things that we have we get from customers all the time was I didn't know you could do that. We get that a lot. And the whole concept of synthesis is to up rate that so that is on the table right away. And by the way, when you want to buy it you are buying a product, you are not buying some mythical marketing message, you are buying products, which then links into the licensing with the good, better, best and things like that. I think that is going to be pretty successful.

ROD HALL: Okay. Can I just -- one other thing I wanted to ask you guys on the virtual stuff. This -- one of the things -- people always ask about pricing but not unit volume. Do you think that -- does unit volume change with this? Because I would think that -- we've seen with virtual machine deployment, application deployment velocity increased. If we automate everything now we are going to see another huge increase in automation, in velocity and deployment,. And I just wonder can you comment on the unit volume side of the virtual equation as opposed to the pricing side?

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: When we look at the data center solutions there, there are multiple ways people are consuming the technology in the data center. So just to explain the unit volume and the increase in that. Some of the large deals we did this year around VEs were targeted at where a customer provides a service and they provide the service to let's say 1,000 users. And instead of taking one device and partitioning that device using virtualization technology it is easier for them to partition a single unit, right, a single VE.

Part of why the strategy has been I call it 10 to 10, pushing our performance down to 10 meg, up to 10 gig and beyond, right. But the concept would be to get small footprints for VEs so you can have lots of those that are specific to a tenant, right. So we think, yes, there will be unit volume increase in that part of the market segment. And we saw some multimillion dollar deals this year that address that specific thing. And there are others in the pipeline. So I think you will see that occur.

JOHN MCADAM: Okay, that's us. I Hope you found it useful and thanks for being attentive and probably next time you will hear us is on the quarterly call.

urn:contentItem:5V5F-30W1-JCMN-Y0TK-00000-00FAANG, Public Trust, Valuations, in 2019: The Read from Menlo Ventures2019-01-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:55ZLexisNexisFAANG, Public Trust, Valuations, in 2019: The Read from Menlo VenturesBernadette Tansey

Jan 10, 2019( Xconomy: http://www.xconomy.com/ Delivered by Newstex) The market caps of some of the most successful tech titans reach as high as $1 trillion. Yet in 2018, perceptions about these dominant companies often reflected uneasiness and doubt—and for some, so did their stock performance.Maybe the mood shift has to do with the fact that the public and government leaders no longer evaluate these tech giants based solely on their spectacular market growth and multi-billion-dollar valuations, but also on the effects of their products, which are woven into almost every aspect of people's lives.Some of these platform companies, taken together, now have a shared nickname: 'FAANG,' which stands for Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix, and Google, a unit of parent company Alphabet. Industry observers see their fates tied together in some ways, and in the aggregate their market value had sunk[1] by more than $700 billion as 2018 drew to a close.Business conditions such as trade wars surely played a part in those losses, but at least some of that slide was due to public scrutiny over controversies like those that thrust Facebook(NASDAQ: FB[2])under the spotlight in 2018. The company, defending against criticisms over data privacy violations and the spread of false 2016 election campaign messages from fake accounts traced to Russia, found user growth slowing[3] persistently.

Its market cap plummeted[4] by more than $100 billion on a single day in July, and hasn't recovered since that period in the summer.Some observers say the FAANG companies slumped because they had been overvalued. Others say these companies are facing new headwinds from regulators that could cut into their profits. Lawmakers are considering ways to rein in the power of global tech companies that control the personal data of millions of people, use it to reap billions in ad revenues and sales, and allegedly squeeze out competitors[5]—or acquire them.Ride-hailing pioneer Uber now hopes to take its place among the commanding platform giants that are publicly traded, through the IPO it plans for this year. But there's speculation that Uber will fall short[6] of the daring $120 billion valuation that some Wall Street bankers have suggested it could establish through the IPO.Xconomy asked a number of business leaders to comment on the lessons of 2018, and forecast some of the patterns we may see in 2019[7]. Two partners from Silicon Valley venture capital firm Menlo Ventures, Venky Ganesan (pictured, second from right) and Matt Murphy (pictured, second from left), were among those who offered their insights. They commented on the FAANG companies, the role of public trust in business success for tech companies, and the stress tests that fundraising will bring for companies with lofty private valuations.Here are their comments, shared via e-mail:Xconomy: What trend or event defined your industry in 2018? What are the implications for 2019?Venky Ganesan: 2018 was a rough year for FAANG—the former kings of the stock market have been dethroned. While Amazon, Uber, and Microsoft lead the pack in terms of public-facing companies, I don't believe there will be a 'new FAANG.'More companies are choosing to remain privately held than ever before. Big tech's relationship with the public and the government is irrevocably changed. Expect regulation and governmental oversight, very similar to what happened to the banking sector.X: World Wide Web founder Tim Berners-Lee has proposed the formulation of a 'Contract for the Web' to mitigate the impacts of tech companies on individual privacy, national and regional strife, and other societal factors. He is asking companies and others to help write it, and pledge to honor it. If you were helping to write the 'Contract for the Web,' what are some of the provisions or principles you would propose? Do you think companies will honor these principles?Ganesan: All tech companies, whether they be consumer, enterprise, startup, or a Fortune 500 company, will need to prove that they can earn the public's trust in 2019.After seeing the very public and very negative backlash felt by the likes of Facebook and Google for their high-profile data breaches, it will be important for tech companies to promise customers that their information is protected. Privacy and how you use data will be key discussion topics going forward.If the industry as a whole is going to evaluate how it treats consumer data, the first step is holding big tech accountable.X: What are the emerging technologies that make it harder for you to predict how well your startup, your startup investment, or your company's new initiatives might remain relevant in the market, for a time period long enough for them to succeed?Matt Murphy: It's less about the emerging technologies and more about the investment strategies behind them. Overall, things are getting harder, not easier, next year in terms of raising capital and fundraising because investors have been betting that any company with a bit of traction will make it big. Unfortunately, that's just not the case for every startup. We'll see a lot of over-investments play out this year, which reveal cracks in the foundation of these over-inflated expectations and valuations.[Editor's note: This is part of aseries of posts[8]sharing thoughts from technology leaders about 2018 trends and 2019 forecasts.]Photo credit: Menlo Ventures Reprints[9] | Share: urn:contentItem:5TSN-WYR1-DYTY-C3YH-00000-00FAANGs ain't what they used to be after $1 trillion fall;Technology Intelligence The tech giants have been beset with woes and now they've hit bear territory, reports Matthew Field2018-11-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:54ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 5FAANGs ain't what they used to be after $1 trillion fallTechnology Intelligence The tech giants have been beset with woes and now they've hit bear territory, reports Matthew FieldMatthew Field

It is a few short months since analysts watched Apple's green ticker climb higher towards the $1 trillion milestone. In a memo to Apple's 120,000 employees on Aug 3, two days later, chief executive Tim Cook praised the company, but urged staff that such financial metrics were "not the most important measure of our success".

"Just as Steve always did in moments like this," Mr Cook wrote, drawing on the legacy of his predecessor Steve Jobs. "We should all look forward to Apple's bright future."

But for investors, that bright future may be a little more distant for Apple and the four other tech stocks which comprise the so-called FAANGs - Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix and Google.

For years, their stellar performance has served as rocket fuel for the wider US market, helping drive a bull run in stocks that has reverberated around the globe.

Yesterday however, all five officially entered bear market territory, meaning they have all dropped 20pc from their highest points. Apple and Alphabet, Google's parent company, are down 20pc, Amazon is down 25pc, Netflix 35pc and Facebook 39pc. Put together, more than $1 trillion has been wiped from their valuations since they touched 52-week highs only a few weeks ago.

The market slump has taken a chunk out of other tech stocks, from chip makers to software providers, as concerns mount over trade tensions between the US and China and a slowdown in Asia has rippled through the industry.

While their share prices have been grabbing the headlines, the giants of Silicon Valley are facing a variety of different challenges.

Shareholders are now pondering the extent to which these tech stocks are the victims of an inevitable correction after a dizzying rise in their valuations over recent months, and to what degree is their fundamental value suffering?

Saturation

Peak iPhone? Peak Facebook? One concern that has been plaguing some of the big tech names is that they are running out of momentum in key markets as rates of growth start to slow. The Facebook app's market penetration in the US was shown to be wobbling at the start of 2018, when the number of daily active users fell for the first time.

Apple, meanwhile, has run into problems that are affecting all smartphone sellers. The simple truth is that almost everyone who is likely to buy an iPhone already owns one.

Apple has not returned to the peaks of iPhone sales it made in 2015, despite reporting record profits. While Apple's market cap hit $1 trillion in August, and for a while continued to climb, it has since dropped to around $882bn.

Not everyone is downcast on the opportunities for growth. "Even though we have seen some saturation on the main Facebook platform, Facebook is still seen as having a stranglehold," says Bill Fisher, an analyst at eMarketer. "The parent company has Instagram, which is seen as the new Facebook. It has been hedging its bets, it has been spreading itself around."

Ben Wood, analyst at CCS Insight, is similarly confident on Apple's return to form. "Apple are making gravity defying margins on the phones that they are selling" despite the slowdown in smartphone demand, he says.

Others believe this is a strategy that may not work forever as consumers grow tired of shelling out such high sums for products that are no longer a novelty.

Regulation and reputation

Potentially the biggest one-day falls in the stock price of the big tech companies in recent weeks have stemmed from damage to the reputation of specific companies. Facebook, above all, has been dented by simmering scandals over privacy, misinformation and the way management has handled them. A string of key departures from some of its core businesses, including the founders of Instagram and WhatsApp, have not helped.

"Facebook is down for a lot of reasons," says Pivotal Research analyst Brian Wieser, a senior Wall Street digital economy expert. "Concerns are mounting on how well the company is run and about management changes."

The threat of further regulation to bring tech companies to heel has not abated. In the US, some states have begun implementing their own data privacy bills to mirror Europe's General Data Protection Regulation. There have also been mounting calls to break the chokehold of some of tech's monopolies - not least Facebook's domination of social media and Amazon's increasingly allencompassing retail empire. Rivals have also been hitting back. Netflix, which has largely been unaffected by reputational tarring that has hit Facebook, is facing growing pressure from a host of rivals - including a new streaming effort from Disney.

Digital ad market

Despite the gloomy outlook of the past week, the digital advertising market, a core driver of Facebook, Google and increasingly Amazon's income, appears to show no signs of slowing. The latest figures from the Interactive Advertising Bureau, a US trade body, suggested ad income grew 23pc in the first half of the year.

Such figures should be cause for celebration for tech investors, but more conservative analysts have said the bigger picture is not as rosy. In a note to clients, Wieser said the long run for the ad market will almost certainly be hit by a slow down.

"Every passing period ... means we get closer to the point in time where growth for digital media owners approaches the level we would expect to see for the overall advertising industry," he said.

The Trump effect

While the US/China trade war tensions may not obviously hit Facebook and Google, both have been hoping to find ways to break into the Chinese market for some time now as an avenue to future growth. With the ante upped by US President Donald Trump, that possibility seems slimmer than ever. Hardware-maker Apple is likely to have felt the trade tensions most directly, given a large number of its suppliers for the iPhone are based in China.

It may also be that shareholders are seeing the end of the big share buybacks that were enabled by President Trump's tax relief for big US companies to bring their cash piles home from overseas.

Red October becomes Red November

The last six weeks have hit global stocks, not just tech, with big falls across markets, oil indexes and asset classes.

And tech stocks are just the worst hit because they have been the most overvalued, some analysts argue.

"The large technology companies (the so-called FAANGs) have been looking frothy for a while, which makes their recent sell-off rather unsurprising," says TS Lombard analyst Dario Perkin.

Etoro analyst Mati Greenspan concurs: "In the tech sector we are seeing shares that are trading 100 times their earnings. Everyone is saying: 'We are now closer to the end of the cycle than we were at the beginning'."

If the markets are coming to the natural conclusion of their bull run, it is trillion-dollar babies of the Big Tech shares that have the furthest to fall.

urn:contentItem:5X0G-TGX1-JDH1-C50P-00000-00FAANG sinks its teeth into almost every aspect of Canadian life. Who is keeping watch?2019-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 0FAANG sinks its teeth into almost every aspect of Canadian life. Who is keeping watch?Tony Wong

We're living in a FAANG world. And, no, it's not a vampire movie, although the metaphor of a behemoth that thrives on our data as its lifeblood might be apt.

Whether you shop for shoes on Amazon, call your mom on your iPhone, click on Facebook for your news or on Netflix and chill on the weekends, FAANG impacts just about every aspect of your life.

It's an acronym for some of the world's biggest technology companies, including Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix and Google. Add in Microsoft and you pretty much have the wealth of some nations in companies that have become superpowers unto themselves.

Combined, the six have annual revenues of approximately $865 billion (U.S.), greater than the GDP of Saudi Arabia, the 18th largest economy in the world based on 2018 figures. (Canada, with a GDP of $1.7 trillion is the 10th largest world economy.) Data has become the new oil.

"How dominant they've become has been amazing," says professor Tyler Chamberlain of the University of Ottawa's Telfer School of Management. "These are truly global companies. The major businesses of the past had international operations. But the scale of the digital companies is unprecedented. They have dominated like no other companies before."

Canada has certainly been a beneficiary of the tech boom. This year, Toronto was ranked as one of the top North American cities for tech talent by commercial real estate consultants CBRE. Toronto's talent pool grew at the fastest pace of 50 markets measured, with 80,100 jobs created in the past five years, making the city the third best market in North America.

Only Silicon Valley (the San Francisco Bay area) and Seattle were ranked higher for their overall talent pools.

While the companies have undoubtedly created great wealth and prosperity for shareholders, the dominance of the big six has also created problems.

"They have, to some, become the robber barons of the modern era," says Chamberlain.

Governments worldwide, including Canada, are grappling with how to regulate the foreign enterprises that are disrupting domestic economies on a massive scale.

That includes issues such as corporate taxation, privacy, fake news, antitrust and even cultural concerns such as contributing to Canadian content.

The Canadian government is looking at ways to regulate and tax the digital entities with a federal review panel that will make recommendations in January. What makes regulation more difficult is that the companies are notoriously secretive, guarding their information and data, while monetizing the data of consumers.

Basic information such as the number of employees or Canadian revenue is not always publicly revealed, making it difficult to gauge the exact footprint of Big Tech on the Canadian economy.

Netflix, for example, doesn't reveal how many viewers are watching their shows. A Netflix Canada spokesperson told the Star "no comment" when asked repeatedly about the most basic information such as how many employees or offices they had in Canada. With an estimated 6.3 million subscribers in Canada alone, according to U.K.-based third-party analysts Comparitech Ltd., the country is the company's fifth-largest market.

Facebook, meanwhile, told The Logic, a news outlet that reports on the innovation economy, that, globally, the company had 30,000 workers in safety and security by the end of 2018. But the company would not reveal a breakdown of the number of employees working in safety and security in Canada.

"It's a major issue how we deal with these tech giants at this point because it will impact us in a significant way down the line," says BMO Financial Group chief economist Doug Porter. "It bears extremely close watching to see what happens because, at the end of the day, it will affect Canadian government revenues fundamentally."

But citizens are demanding change. In August, a coalition of Canadian arts organizations representing producers, writers, publishers, directors, actors and artists launched a pressure campaign demanding that political parties update digital laws to protect Canadian culture. The #SaveOurCulture campaign is aimed at politicians running in the October federal election.

"Digital has not only transformed the ways in which cultural content is accessed, it has also disrupted the cultural economy without adapting the rules of the game," said spokesperson Bill Skolnik, co-chair of the campaign and executive director of the Directors Guild of Canada.

Canada's Competition Bureau told the Star it is "monitoring" tech giants for anti-competitive behaviour in the wake of a sweeping U.S. Justice Department investigation as well as an inquiry by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. Regulators are looking at whether the digital companies are abusing their power by stifling innovation and competition. As a result, Canada's Competition Bureau launched a wide-ranging inquiry this month on how the digital economy may be harming Canadian business, asking anyone with information to come forward.

"Since certain digital markets tend towards a "winner takes all" outcome, firms in these markets have a strong incentive to adopt strategies that increase the likelihood the market tips in their favour," says the bureau in a paper.

On Friday, New York Attorney General Letitia James announced her office was organizing a multi-state antitrust probe into Facebook, while another group of states was preparing to launch a separate antitrust probe targeting Google.

The stakes are certainly high: Facebook was recently fined a record $5 billion by the U.S. Federal Trade Commission over privacy violations, and the European Commission just opened an antitrust investigation into Amazon.

Facebook has been on the firing line because of its impact on the 2016 U.S. presidential election and issues of foreign interference. With the federal election next month, Canada is also on alert.

"They all have their own sets of problems and issues. But Facebook, especially, because of their prominence on social media and impact on culture and communication," says the University of Ottawa's Chamberlain. "It really puts them in the spotlight where they get a lot of attention, making it more difficult and complex."

Netflix, meanwhile, competes with Canadian broadcasters such as CTV, Global and Citytv, but does not have an obligation to contribute funds to produce Canadian shows.

And tax rules that were made during the heyday of print journalism puts legacy publishers at a disadvantage compared to platforms such as Google and Facebook. They have grown so large they now command almost three-quarters of all digital advertising dollars.

The digital economy has also put a squeeze on artists, including writers, musicians and actors struggling to attain the kind of middle-class living status that, while never assured, seems more difficult to attain now than in the past.

Interestingly, a government bureaucrat didn't coin the term FAANG, but it was popularized by CNBC Mad Money host Jim Cramer, who used it to describe high-performing technology stocks. The original FANG consisted of only four high-performing stocks - Facebook, Amazon, Netflix and Google (owned by parent company, Alphabet). Since then, it's been expanded in various versions, but the old guard of Apple and Microsoft - because of their market dominance and importance - are worth adding to the list.

The dominance of big tech companies has some critics calling for them to be broken up into smaller companies. That's not a new reaction, says Chamberlain.

"If you go back in history when you have these dominant firms, there is always pushback, a desire to split them up and tear them down. But the reality is market forces say they certainly won't be there forever."

While Facebook is being scrutinized now, Chamberlain says it wasn't that long ago that Microsoft, for example, was demonized as the thousand-pound gorilla that threatened to stifle development of other companies.

In 2008, the company was fined the equivalent of $1.35 billion (U.S.) by the European Union over antitrust violations.

Since then, Microsoft has transformed itself from essentially a device-based company to a mobile and cloud company, as the negative attention has focused on the other tech leaders.

"Someone's head is always on the chopping block, but that changes. What everyone is afraid of today will invariably change tomorrow," says Chamberlain. "That doesn't mean we shouldn't regulate and have rules. But it's good to have perspective."

BMO economist Porter says a chart of the biggest firms in earlier decades would look far different than the FAANG-dominated chart of today. Traditionally, automobile, real estate, oil and bricks and mortar retailing were the bread and butter stocks.

"We unquestionably have a very different picture at the top this time around," says Porter. "But for Canada, success in technology goes beyond the FAANG companies."

Porter says there is a wave of smaller homegrown companies that are doing exceptionally well in areas such as artificial intelligence, but are under the radar that could one day be part of the next FAANG.

"It's maybe something that is not as celebrated as it should be. But we are seeing solid employment gains in the technology sector and the birth of a lot of very interesting companies and that bodes well for Canada and for the future. That is the bulwark against the dominance of FAANG."

Tony Wong is the Star's technology reporter covering big tech, disinformation and regulation. Follow him on Twitter: @tonydwong

As a result, Canada's Competition Bureau launched a wide-ranging inquiry this month on how the digital economy may be harming Canadian business, asking anyone with information to come forward.

"Since certain digital markets tend towards a "winner takes all" outcome, firms in these markets have a strong incentive to adopt strategies that increase the likelihood the market tips in their favour," says the bureau in a paper.

On Friday, New York Attorney General Letitia James announced her office was organizing a multi-state antitrust probe into Facebook, while another group of states was preparing to launch a separate antitrust probe targeting Google.

The stakes are certainly high: Facebook was recently fined a record $5 billion by the U.S. Federal Trade Commission over privacy violations, and the European Commission just opened an antitrust investigation into Amazon.

Facebook has been on the firing line because of its impact on the 2016 U.S. presidential election and issues of foreign interference. With the federal election next month, Canada is also on alert.

"They all have their own sets of problems and issues. But Facebook, especially, because of their prominence on social media and impact on culture and communication," says the University of Ottawa's Chamberlain. "It really puts them in the spotlight where they get a lot of attention, making it more difficult and complex."

Netflix, meanwhile, competes with Canadian broadcasters such as CTV, Global and Citytv, but does not have an obligation to contribute funds to produce Canadian shows.

And tax rules that were made during the heyday of print journalism puts legacy publishers at a disadvantage compared to platforms such as Google and Facebook. They have grown so large they now command almost three-quarters of all digital advertising dollars.

The digital economy has also put a squeeze on artists, including writers, musicians and actors struggling to attain the kind of middle-class living status that, while never assured, seems more difficult to attain now than in the past.

Interestingly, a government bureaucrat didn't coin the term FAANG, but it was popularized by CNBC Mad Money host Jim Cramer, who used it to describe high-performing technology stocks. The original FANG consisted of only four high-performing stocks - Facebook, Amazon, Netflix and Google (owned by parent company, Alphabet). Since then, it's been expanded in various versions, but the old guard of Apple and Microsoft - because of their market dominance and importance - are worth adding to the list.

The dominance of big tech companies has some critics calling for them to be broken up into smaller companies. That's not a new reaction, says Chamberlain.

"If you go back in history when you have these dominant firms, there is always pushback, a desire to split them up and tear them down. But the reality is market forces say they certainly won't be there forever."

While Facebook is being scrutinized now, Chamberlain says it wasn't that long ago that Microsoft, for example, was demonized as the thousand-pound gorilla that threatened to stifle development of other companies.

In 2008, the company was fined the equivalent of $1.35 billion (U.S.) by the European Union over antitrust violations.

Since then, Microsoft has transformed itself from essentially a device-based company to a mobile and cloud company, as the negative attention has focused on the other tech leaders.

"Someone's head is always on the chopping block, but that changes. What everyone is afraid of today will invariably change tomorrow," says Chamberlain. "That doesn't mean we shouldn't regulate and have rules. But it's good to have perspective."

BMO economist Porter says a chart of the biggest firms in earlier decades would look far different than the FAANG-dominated chart of today. Traditionally, automobile, real estate, oil and bricks and mortar retailing were the bread and butter stocks.

"We unquestionably have a very different picture at the top this time around," says Porter. "But for Canada, success in technology goes beyond the FAANG companies."

Porter says there is a wave of smaller homegrown companies that are doing exceptionally well in areas such as artificial intelligence, but are under the radar that could one day be part of the next FAANG.

"It's maybe something that is not as celebrated as it should be. But we are seeing solid employment gains in the technology sector and the birth of a lot of very interesting companies and that bodes well for Canada and for the future. That is the bulwark against the dominance of FAANG."

Tony Wong is the Star's technology reporter covering big tech, disinformation and regulation. Follow him on Twitter: @tonydwong

urn:contentItem:5TTM-KSR1-F021-60S5-00000-00FAANGs lose their bite, but they are not about to fall2018-11-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:55ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY INTELLIGENCEVersion:1FAANGs lose their bite, but they are not about to fallBy James Titcomb

Earlier this month, at a meeting of his employees, Jeff Bezos told his staff that "one day Amazon will fail" . Asked a question about the collapse of the retail institution Sears, Bezos said that large companies are often only dominant for around 30 years, and that he saw his job as delaying his company's collapse for as long as possible.

A brief look at US stock markets last week might have suggested that moment is coming for Amazon sooner rather than later. The company's market value, which passed a trillion dollars earlier in the summer, has fallen by a quarter in a prolonged tech slump.

Bezos's personal wealth has tumbled by $42bn (33bn) since the start of August, or around $17m an hour, although he remains by some distance the world's richest person.

Amazon is not alone, however. The last few weeks has been the worst period for big technology companies since the financial crisis, at least in stock market terms.

The "FAANGs" - Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Alphabet - the five companies that have epitomised tech's stock market boom in the decade since the crisis, have all lost between 25pc and 40pc of their value since their peaks this summer. In market value terms, their collective decline has added up to more than one trillion dollars . 

Apple is now on the verge of being overtaken as the world's most valuable company by fusty old Microsoft for the first time in eight years: on Friday, their market capitalisations differed by a mere $26bn. Some tech companies have fared even worse, such as the chipmaker Nvidia, which has lost half of its value in a month.

FAANGs cut down to size Declines since peak

There are several reasons for this broad sell-off. Rising interest rates are making equities comparatively less appealing to investors. The Trump tax cuts, which brought hundreds of billions in overseas cash back to the US and were spent on share buybacks, are wearing off. 

And global growth prospects for 2019 are fading. These phenomena affect the whole stock market, but high-growth tech shares more than most, because they are seen as riskier than the more reliable consumer staples.

But ignore the wider economic picture, and its easy to see things another way. Apple is not selling as many iPhones as investors had hoped. Earlier this month, the company announced that it would stop telling investors how many of each gadget it sells during quarterly results, which investors interpreted as a sign that the figures would not be as pretty as they had been in the past. 

This was compounded by a flurry of announcements from component suppliers that suggested iPhone production orders had been slashed. Last week, it was reported that Apple was considering cutting the price of its recently-released phones, something that would be an extremely unusual move.

Or look at Facebook. The company's recent share decline has coincided with yet another scandal at the social networking giant, this time over its use of a shady PR firm that attempted to smear its rivals. The revelations have led to more calls for regulation of the company, and left Mark Zuckerberg and his second-in-command Sheryl Sandberg under pressure to restore its reputation, something they have failed to do.

Among the other FAANGs there is also a lingering feeling that the unchecked growth enjoyed in recent years might not continue in the future. Combine this with a growing distrust of big tech, and one might think that the share price fall since this summer is only the beginning of the end. 

Bezos' statement that all things come to an end has been especially true of technology companies. The sector has been uniquely prone to bubbles, and success is never guaranteed in an industry where a teenager can create a giant-killer in their garage.

If another economic crisis is round the corner, nobody knows how the tech companies will fare. Yes, four of the five were on the stock market during the 2008 crash (Facebook being the exception), but their businesses were completely different - Apple was an iPod company, Netflix rented out DVDs in the post, Amazon and Alphabet were a fraction of their current size.

But it would be a mistake to think that the FAANGs are going anywhere, or that they have peaked. Unlike in previous tech bubbles, where fever got ahead of profits, the tech giants make huge amounts of money. Netflix is an exception here, but could be very profitable if it wanted to stop investing in growth.

Apple, Amazon, Facebook and Alphabet's statuses as the world's most valuable companies is not a results of outlandish earnings multiples or irrational optimism. It reflects their dominance in the modern economy, as well as their impressive staying power. For all the talk of peak iPhone, Apple still sells millions of them a week, and at ever-higher prices.

The business models of Google and Facebook are routinely criticised, but no politician seems willing to regulate them, and the companies themselves are ruthless in stamping out competition. Amazon has no shortage of growth potential - in addition to the internet's growing share of shopping, it is starting to open brick and mortar stores.

The FAANGs may have lost some of their bite, but they are not about to fall.

urn:contentItem:5XFK-0BF1-JCJY-G2WD-00000-00FAANGs: who are the winners of the future?2019-11-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:44:55ZLexisNexisFAANGs: who are the winners of the future?Megan Boxall

The front runner in the tussle at the top of the global leaderboard of public companies differs depending on metric. Walmart (US:WMT) sells more products than any other company. In the year to January 2019, it reported $514bn (£393bn) of total revenues - more than twice the annual revenues of digital retailer Amazon (US:AMZN). Apple (US:AAPL) tops the profit table, with $13.7bn of net income in the three months to September 2019. For company assets, head to the banking sector where JP Morgan (US:JPM) has $2.8 trillion of total assets.

But in the battle for market capitalisation, companies in the tech industry are the only real contenders for the top spot. In the past decade, as stock markets have strengthened, digital behemoths have claimed higher valuations than any company in history. In 2019, three of them have hit a peak market capitalisation of more than $1 trillion.

It is hardly surprising that investors value these companies so highly. Tech has infiltrated almost every industry in the world and digital companies account for seven of the top 10 most valuable brands, according to Kantar US Insights. With the growth of the tech industry unlikely to let up, companies that can benefit from the changes or - even better - drive them, are likely to remain favoured by global investors.

But there is a potential downside to the rising use of technology across multiple industries: if traditionally non-tech companies gain the digital expertise that once belonged exclusively to businesses like the FAANGs - the acronym applied to five of the world's biggest tech beasts, Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Alphabet's Google - is the era of tech company dominance coming to an end? And will the tech titans be able to retain their positions as the most valuable companies in the world?

Beware the ubiquity of technology

Netflix (US:NFLX) is a prime example of these dangers. In the next few months it will face its first real competition when Walt Disney (US:DIS) and AT&T's (US:T.) HBO launch their own streaming platforms. To deal with the battle, the company has a $10bn content budget for 2019 and is churning out more original titles than ever before. Chief executive Reid Hastings acknowledges this threat. "We did well during the first decade of streaming," he wrote in his third quarter letter to shareholders. "We've been preparing for this new wave of competition for a long time."

Preparation is all well and good, but competing with two of the world's most loved production companies on their own turf is not going to be easy. Netflix has won a global audience of 158m thanks to its content recommendation features, ease of use and ability to satisfy its audience's love of binge-watching. If DisneyPlus or HBO Max can match Netflix's technological expertise, they can let their superior production skills win over new customers. Netflix will then struggle to continue to maintain its quarterly revenue growth, which has averaged 28 per cent in the past three years.

Facebook (US: FB.) could go the same way. Alongside Google, it has gained a duopoly in the advertising industry built on a remarkable ability to collect data from an enormous global user base. But more media companies are beginning to use tech to capture large, targeted audiences, thus encroaching on Facebook and Google's space. The two companies' share of the digital advertising industry has begun to fall in the past few years.

PE based on FactSet forecasts.

Compounding this potential issue is the fact that Facebook has a major image problem. True, third-quarter numbers helped to expel any immediate doubt about the popularity of its platforms (which include Instagram and WhatsApp): monthly active users rose 8 per cent and advertising revenue was up 28 per cent to $17.4bn. But that doesn't take away from the fact that the company has been criticised for supporting addictive algorithms, allowing political advertising and damaging mental health. Regulators don't want Facebook to continue to make huge amounts of money from the personal data of its customers. A clampdown could eventually restrict its advertising sales.

The same is true of Twitter (US:TWTR), which fell short of revenue and profit guidance in the third quarter. Advertising revenue in the quarter might have risen 8 per cent to $702m, but that was significantly lower than the $756m forecast by FactSet - not good enough considering Twitter generates 85 per cent of its revenue from advertising. By contrast, fellow social media group Snap (US:SNAP) managed to beat analysts' expectations after adding 7m daily active users in the third quarter to send revenues up 50 per cent. But, like Facebook and Twitter, it also relies on gathering personal data of users. If the model comes under threat from regulation, there won't be much room for any of these new age media companies to grow.

The superiority of software

Apple's troubles start in China where the rising popularity of Huawei mobile phones has cut into the market long-dominated by the iPhone. Apple has been forced to trim its prices, which sent product sales down 1.5 per cent in the third quarter, despite reports of unexpectedly high demand for the new iPhone 11.

Fortunately, another surge in the group's services division - which includes its iOS operating system - helped make up the shortfall. Apple's services business generated gross margins of over 64 per cent, compared with 32 per cent in the products division. This level of profitability is more akin to software giants such as Microsoft (US:MSFT) and Adobe (US:ADBE), which generated gross margins of 69 per cent and 85 per cent in their respective third quarters.

The global software industry is in its prime thanks to a rise in the subscription business model, which was pioneered by Adobe when it switched from a licensing business in 2013. In the third quarter of 2019, 90 per cent of Adobe's revenues came from reliable, recurring subscriptions, compared with 28 per cent in 2013. Subscriptions require very low ongoing expenditure, meaning the bulk of Adobe's costs are sales and marketing ($812m in Q3) and research and development ($490m in Q3) - both of which in turn drive revenue growth. In the three months to August 2019, revenue rose 24 per cent to $2.8bn.

Many of the world's software companies have jumped on the subscription bandwagon and are reaping the rewards. Intuit (US:INTU) - which will release its fiscal first-quarter results on 21 November - recently announced that it expects 10-11 per cent revenue growth in the year to July 2020, driven by strong demand for its QuickBooks software subscription.

But growth is most impressive at the king of all software companies: Microsoft. In the three months to September 2019, the world's largest public company reported a 14 per cent increase in revenues and 22 per cent increase in earnings - substantially ahead of analyst expectations.

A trio of tech titans of the future

Microsoft's Azure was the company's standout product in the quarter, reporting 59 per cent revenue growth to drive sales in its intelligent cloud division up 27 per cent to $10.8bn. Amazon's cloud business, AWS, was similarly impressive, with revenues up 35 per cent to $9bn and operating profits up 9 per cent to $2.3bn. The two companies boast a combined 63 per cent share of the fast-growing cloud computing market, which means they are in an enviable position as the world's reliance on cloud-hosted data storage continues to grow.

Alphabet (US:GOOGL) is also well placed to benefit from the growth of the cloud. True, its market share (9 per cent) isn't as impressive as Microsoft or Amazon, but it stands above its peers in its ability to understand and manipulate data. Extensive investment in artificial intelligence, including its 2014 acquisition of British AI start-up DeepMind Technologies, means the company can sell its pioneering AI alongside its cloud hosting services to companies seeking to make better use of their data.

Cloud and AI, which sit alongside Androids, Maps, Play and hardware in Google's non-advertising division, reported $6.4bn of sales in the third quarter - a 39 per cent increase compared with the previous year, which reflects the company's focus on investing in products set to drive growth in the future. Amazon is employing a similar strategy. In 2019, the group will spend $800m on improving its logistics, including automating its warehouses, improving the capabilities of its drones and investing in driverless lorries. The period of heavy spending seems to have spooked investors, who have sent the share price down 10 per cent since its summer peak, but chief executive Jeff Bezos insists the investment will drive even more impressive growth. In the third quarter, revenues leapt 24 per cent to $70bn - well ahead of expectations.

Alphabet and Amazon might have been the only two FAANGs to miss third-quarter expectations, but they are readying their businesses for the demands of the future better than many of their big tech peers. Microsoft is also very well placed to benefit from changing consumer and industry demands. By contrast, companies that haven't continued to innovate will struggle to live up to the expectations of their lofty valuations. So, while the world's most valuable companies are likely to remain tech-orientated, we think investors will have to be more selective with their choices and not simply buy shares in a company because it claims digital expertise. The FAANGs must be prepared for the future - we think Microsoft, Amazon and Alphabet are the picks of the US tech sector.
